Being a new parent is stressful!
Being a new parent is stressful!

Two Ways of Coping with Stress
Two Ways of Coping with Stress

Problem Management
Problem Management

Emotional Regulation

Two Ways of Coping with Stress
Two Ways of Coping with Stress

Emotional Regulation
Emotional Regulation

Problem Management If parents believe a solution is possible - they will try to find ways to fix the problem.

Two Ways of Coping with Stress

Problem Management If parents believe a solution is possible - they will try to find ways to fix the problem.

Emotional Regulation If parents don’t • believe a solution is possible - they won’t try to solve the problem. Instead, they will try to calm themselves down.
Emotional Regulation

themselves down.

New Tool!
New Tool!

Promoting Positive Interactions
Promoting Positive Interactions

Directions:
Directions:

Read assigned scenario, and answer the questions. All of the babies in these scenarios are healthy, eating well, and growing appropriately.
Read assigned scenario, and answer the
questions. All of the babies in these
scenarios are healthy, eating well, and
growing appropriately.

TIP: There is no need to ask about the number
TIP: There is no need to ask about the number

of wet or poopie diapers!
of wet or poopie diapers!

Example Scenario
Example Scenario

Dad is bottle-feeding 3-month old Roberto as he sits in your counseling office. As you watch, Roberto stops sucking, kicks his feet, starts to fuss, and tries to turn his head away. The father jiggles the bottle until the baby starts sucking again. The dad asks, “How do I get Roberto to finish his bottle?”
Dad is bottle-feeding 3-month old Roberto as he
sits in your counseling office. As you watch,
Roberto stops sucking, kicks his feet, starts to
fuss, and tries to turn his head away. The
father jiggles the bottle until the baby starts
sucking again. The dad asks, “How do I get
Roberto to finish his bottle?”

Scenario 1
Scenario 1

During her WIC appointment, Mom tells you that 4-year-old Daniel just loves to play with 3-week- old Amber. You watch as Daniel puts his face very near baby Amber’s face and then she yawns, opens and closes her eyes, and tries to turn away. Daniel then begins to sing a loud song, you watch as Amber stiffens her hands and points her fingers. The mother smiles and says, “Daniel just loves playing with Amber but sometimes she gets so fussy and I don’t know why.”
During her WIC appointment, Mom tells you that
4-year-old Daniel just loves to play with 3-week-
old Amber. You watch as Daniel puts his face very
near baby Amber’s face and then she yawns,
opens and closes her eyes, and tries to turn away.
Daniel then begins to sing a loud song, you watch
as Amber stiffens her hands and points her
fingers. The mother smiles and says, “Daniel just
loves playing with Amber but sometimes she gets
so fussy and I don’t know why.”

Scenario 2
Scenario 2

Bradley looks proudly at his 2-month-old son, Jonathan during their WIC appointment. He talks about his son’s interest in solid foods. He has been giving him ‘tastes’ of table food because he can tell by the way the baby looks at food that he wants to eat more than just breast milk.
Bradley looks proudly at his 2-month-old son,
Jonathan during their WIC appointment. He
talks about his son’s interest in solid foods. He
has been giving him ‘tastes’ of table food
because he can tell by the way the baby looks at
food that he wants to eat more than just breast
milk.

Tip: Think about what cues Jonathan is giving to his Dad at home.
Tip: Think about what cues Jonathan is giving to
his Dad at home. h i s
D a d
a t
h o m e .

Scenario 3
Scenario 3

On the nutrition questions form Sara answers “no” to question #10, “Does your baby seem satisfied after feeding?” When you ask her about this, Sara tells you she is thinking of weaning Carlos, who is a large 3 week old, because he is “never satisfied” after breastfeeding. She tells you that Carlos will start to fuss and move around just a few minutes after each feeding. Sara is sure she doesn’t have enough milk, even though Carlos is growing well.
On the nutrition questions form Sara answers
“no” to question #10, “Does your baby seem
satisfied after feeding?” When you ask her
about this, Sara tells you she is thinking of
weaning Carlos, who is a large 3 week old,
because he is “never satisfied” after
breastfeeding. She tells you that Carlos will
start to fuss and move around just a few
minutes after each feeding. Sara is sure she
doesn’t have enough milk, even though Carlos
is growing well.

Scenario 4
Scenario 4

Susan comes to the desk to ask if she can get some help with breastfeeding. She tells you she is not sure when she’s supposed to feed her 7-day-old baby. You notice the baby is moving around in the car seat, his eyes are open and he is rooting.
Susan comes to the desk to ask if she can
get some help with breastfeeding. She tells
you she is not sure when she’s supposed to
feed her 7-day-old baby. You notice the
baby is moving around in the car seat, his
eyes are open and he is rooting.
